security: This document outlines the process for releasing information under the JFK Assassination Records Collection Act, including the potential release of names and associated agency relationships. Specifically, the document states: 'THE IMPACT OF THE RELEASE OF THE RELATIONSHIP OF YOUR TRUE NAME AND THE AGENCY WILL HAVE TO BE LOOKED AT CAREFULLY TO DETERMINE THE VIABILITY OF CONTINUED COVER PROTECTION.' Releasing this information could compromise the identities and cover of former employees, thereby harming national security.
summary: This document outlines the process for complying with the JFK Assassination Records Collection Act of 1992, particularly regarding the release of names appearing in reviewed documents, and requests station assistance in contacting a former employee in Costa Rica to inform them of potential public release of their information.
summary_one_paragraph: A CIA cable, dated June 30, 1997, directs the San Jose station to contact a former employee residing in Costa Rica who retired under cover, informing them that their name appears in documents being reviewed for public release under the JFK Assassination Records Collection Act of 1992. The message provides a tearline letter explaining the implications of the Act, the potential release of personal information unless exceptions apply, the process for contesting the release, and addresses frequently asked questions about the process.
title: WITHHELD
